sections.text: Irene Shen: Carl, good to see you again. Thanks for making time for a second call. Last time you mentioned you’re trying to tighten up who you target—especially splitting messaging between SMB and mid-market. Is that still the priority for Ridgeway Lumen Telecom?
Carl Burke: Yeah, it is. We’ve got decent traction in SMB, but mid-market is inconsistent. We’re trying to be clearer on why we win and why we lose.

Irene Shen: Perfect—that’s exactly where Customer_Analyzer tends to help. Today I wanted to focus on one piece: the Positioning Recommendations feature. It takes the signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding survey responses, product usage, support tickets, call notes—and turns it into segment-specific messaging blocks. So you’d get one set of positioning for SMB and another for mid-market, grounded in what’s actually driving fit and the language customers use.

Carl Burke: Okay. We looked at the deck you sent. I’m still trying to understand how much work this is going to be on our side. And I’m also wary of tools that spit out “recommended messaging” that isn’t really true in the field.

Irene Shen: Totally fair. Let me break it down in practical terms. For your use case—two ICP tiers—we’d set up two segments and then generate: a segment-specific value proposition, top use cases, differentiators, proof points to collect, plus objection-handling. And it’s not just a report—it’s editable blocks you can paste into a landing page hero, outbound email openers, or sales deck bullets.

Carl Burke: That’s the part that makes me nervous, honestly. If it’s auto-generating, it can become a black box. My team’s going to ask, “Why did it decide that?” And if we can’t explain it, we won’t use it.

Irene Shen: I hear you. The way we address that is by linking each recommendation back to the drivers and evidence. So when it suggests a differentiator for mid-market, it shows what signals drove it—like higher usage of a specific workflow, or repeated language in tickets or calls. The goal is that marketing and sales can look at it and say, “Yes, we recognize this,” or “No, that’s off—let’s adjust.”
Carl Burke: When you say “shows what signals drove it,” what does that actually look like? Is it like a source citation? Or just a generic explanation?

Irene Shen: It’s more like a rationale panel: what inputs were used, what themes it detected, and examples of customer language it’s pulling from. For example, it might surface that mid-market prospects repeatedly mention “handoff between regional teams” and “time-to-resolution reporting,” and then those become proof points and email angles.
Carl Burke: But we have a lot of messy data. CRM fields aren’t clean. Call notes are inconsistent. Support tickets can be noisy. I worry it’ll make confident recommendations based on garbage inputs.

Irene Shen: That’s a real risk with any system using existing data. What we typically do is start narrow: pick the sources that are most reliable—say CRM closed-won/lost plus a slice of support tickets—and generate an initial draft for SMB and mid-market. Then you review it with your sales leaders and tweak. It’s meant to speed up the iteration, not replace judgment.

Carl Burke: The “speed up” part is nice. But we’ve been burned before. We tried an analytics tool that promised “ICP scoring,” and it basically told us what we already knew, but with a lot of math we couldn’t validate.

Irene Shen: Understood. Customer_Analyzer is similar in spirit but we’ve tried to make the outputs more actionable—especially the positioning blocks. Instead of just saying “mid-market is a 72 fit,” it’s: “Here’s the recommended value prop for mid-market. Here are the use cases that correlate with expansions. Here are the objections you need to preempt.” Then you can put it directly into your landing page and outbound.

Carl Burke: Still—how do I know it’s not just pattern-matching buzzwords? Like, we sell telecom solutions. There’s a lot of generic “reliability, uptime, cost savings” language out there. I don’t want another tool telling us to say the same tired stuff.

Irene Shen: That’s exactly why we focus on observed customer language, not generic templates. If your best SMB customers talk about “getting installs scheduled without back-and-forth” and your mid-market wins talk about “consolidating vendors across regions,” those are distinct angles. The output should reflect the real phrases and themes coming from your data.
Carl Burke: “Should” is doing a lot of work there.

Irene Shen: Fair. Let me ask a pointed question—what would make you confident? If we could show you, for one segment, the top three differentiators and the exact evidence behind them, would that address the black-box concern?

Carl Burke: It would help. But there’s another issue: our messaging is complicated because we have different product lines. SMB might buy one bundle, mid-market buys another. If the tool creates one narrative, it may not reflect how we actually sell.

Irene Shen: Great nuance. We can model segments by bundle or product line too—but to keep this second call focused, I’d propose we start with the simplest version: SMB vs mid-market for your primary bundle that generated interest last time. Then we can extend it once the team trusts the workflow.
Carl Burke: That sounds like a pilot. We’re not really in a place to start new pilots right now. Budgets are tight, and leadership is asking for immediate pipeline impact.

Irene Shen: Understood. The way teams usually justify it is by tying it to conversion and cycle time. If your outbound and landing pages are dialed for each tier, you should see better meeting rates and fewer “not a fit” calls. Can I ask—what’s the biggest friction right now in mid-market? Is it top-of-funnel conversion, or deals stalling later?
Carl Burke: Top of funnel. We get meetings, but they’re lower quality than we want. And when we do get serious buyers, they grill us on specifics and we’re not always consistent.

Irene Shen: That maps well to the Positioning Recommendations output—because it includes objection handling and proof points to collect. For mid-market, you’d get a playbook that says: “They’ll ask about deployment timeline, integration, SLA, reporting.” Then it tells you what proof to gather—case study snippets, metrics, references.
Carl Burke: But again—where does it get that? We don’t have a perfect library of objections categorized. It’s in people’s heads or scattered in Gong and notes.

Irene Shen: Right, and that’s why it ingests those unstructured sources. But I don’t want to oversell. If you don’t have consistent call recordings or notes, the objection-handling may be thinner until more data is in place.
Carl Burke: That’s part of the problem. We’re still standardizing. And I don’t want a tool that requires us to fix our entire data foundation to get value.

Irene Shen: That’s fair. There’s some minimum bar—if the inputs are too sparse or messy, outputs degrade. We can still get value from the sources you trust, but I don’t want you to buy something that you can’t operationalize.

Carl Burke: Exactly. Also, I talked to our marketing lead after your last email. She’s worried the team will treat the generated messaging as “approved” and push it live without enough review. And if it’s wrong, it damages credibility.

Irene Shen: That’s a good governance concern. We position the messaging blocks as drafts—editable and reviewable. But I hear you: how teams use tools matters. We can set permissions and workflows, but it won’t replace internal review.
Carl Burke: So we’re back to: we still need to do the work, plus now we manage another tool.

Irene Shen: You would still do review, yes. The goal is reducing the blank-page time and making the rationale clearer. But if your team isn’t ready to incorporate it into the process—or leadership wants immediate pipeline impact without any iteration time—this might not be the right quarter.

Carl Burke: That’s where I’m landing. I like the idea. I’m not convinced it’ll be accurate enough with our current data, and I don’t have appetite for anything that feels like a black box. If we revisit after we clean up CRM and standardize call notes, it could make more sense.

Irene Shen: I appreciate the directness. Before we close it out—would it be helpful if I sent a concrete example of what the evidence-linked positioning output looks like? Not a generic slide—an annotated sample so you can evaluate whether it feels explainable.
Carl Burke: You can send it, sure. But I want to set expectations: we’re not buying anything this month.

Irene Shen: Understood. I’ll send an annotated sample and a short checklist of “minimum data inputs” so you can assess readiness. If it’s helpful, we can also schedule a short follow-up in, say, six to eight weeks to see if conditions changed.
Carl Burke: That’s fine. Send the sample and the checklist. And we’ll see where we are next quarter.
Irene Shen: Sounds good. Thanks, Carl—this was helpful. I’ll follow up by end of day with those materials and a couple of suggested next steps that don’t require a formal pilot.
Carl Burke: Great. Talk soon.
